name: Frank Darabont
trademark: Frequently makes adaptations of stories or novels by Stephen King.

name: Francis Ford Coppola
trademark: Frequently casts Robert Duvall, the late John Cazale, Nicolas Cage, Diane Keaton, Matt Dillon, Harrison Ford, Laurence Fishburne and Marlon Brando.

name: Christopher Nolan
trademark: His films' protagonists have mostly lost their loved ones and/or failed in love, a circumstance that causes them turn into malevolent and/or apathetic forever. (e.g. Leonard in Memento (2000) has lost his wife in a brutal murder in the past, Bruce Wayne in Batman Begins (2005) has lost Rachel Dawes' faith in him throughout the film, Borden in The Prestige (2006) does not get his wife's love ...

name: Sidney Lumet
trademark: Highly dialogue driven films, with a lot of speeches and dramatic verbal duels.

name: Steven Spielberg
trademark: He is an ardent champion of the "cutting-in-camera" philosophy

name: Peter Jackson
trademark: Frequently set his movies in Wellington, New Zealand

name: Quentin Tarantino
trademark: Prefers to start most of his films with a scene before the main titles are shown

name: David Fincher
trademark: Frequently collaborates with Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross for musical scores

name: Robert Zemeckis
trademark: [Opening long-take] Often utilizes long, complicated opening shots (Back to the Future (1985), Forrest Gump (1994), Contact (1997)).

name: Irvin Kershner
trademark: Sometimes shows a robot or a cyborg being dismantled (e.g. Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back (1980) and RoboCop 2 (1990)).

name: Lana Wachowski
trademark: Frequently casts Joe Pantoliano and Hugo Weaving

name: Martin Scorsese
trademark: Frequently sets his films in New York City

name: Milos Forman
trademark: Bio-pics about unlovable celebrities (Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Larry Flynt, Andy Kaufman)

name: Frank Capra
trademark: Often cast James Stewart, Gary Cooper, and Cary Grant

name: Jonathan Demme
trademark: Frequently casts locals to the shooting locations of his films, some of whom are non-actors.

name: George Lucas
trademark: His films usually feature a battle scene which takes place around a large shaft  or pit.

name: Luc Besson
trademark: As seen in Taxi and The Transporter, very distinctive car chase scenes focusing on very low camera shots very close to the front bumper of a fast moving (and often rather mundane) car (transporters Renault 5) with a lot of sideways swerving movment (though traffic or other). Nearly always to a French hiphop soundtrack.

name: Roger Allers
trademark: No info

name: Charles Chaplin
trademark: Despite film portrayals of him having brown eyes, Charlie actually had striking blue eyes

name: Bryan Singer
trademark: Frequently uses music by John Ottman

name: Roman Polanski
trademark: By the end of his films, the protagonist often meets an uncertain, melancholic future (The Ninth Gate (1999), The Ghost Writer (2010), Rosemary's Baby (1968), Chinatown (1974) and Macbeth (1971)).

name: James Cameron
trademark: Often features shots of large explosions, crashes, gunshots, etc. in the background with people running away in the foreground. These shots were used heavily in Terminator 2: Judgment Day (1991) and True Lies (1994) but also in other films.

name: Tony Kaye
trademark: Use of flashbacks and cutaways

name: Ridley Scott
trademark: His stunning visuals - he personally sketches most of his own storyboards, left-handed, with great artistic style (The Duellists (1977), Alien (1979), Blade Runner (1982), Legend (1985), Black Rain (1989), Thelma & Louise (1991), 1492: Conquest of Paradise (1992), Gladiator (2000), Black Hawk Down (2001), Kingdom of Heaven (2005), American Gangster (2007), Body of Lies (2008)).

name: Alfred Hitchcock
trademark: Always began episodes of Alfred Hitchcock Presents (1955) with "Good evening"

name: Damien Chazelle
trademark: His films often revolve around people who are defined by their potential talent and ambition

name: Thomas Kail
trademark: No info

name: Sergio Leone
trademark: Frequently worked with Tonino Delli Colli and Ennio Morricone

name: Michael Curtiz
trademark: No info

name: Stanley Kubrick
trademark: [Beginning Voice-over] Paths of Glory (1957), Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb (1964) and A Clockwork Orange (1971) all begin with a voice over, and The Killing (1956) features narration.

name: Todd Phillips
trademark: Frequently casts Matt Walsh, Juliette Lewis, Zach Galifianakis, Vince Vaughn, and Will Ferrell.

name: Billy Wilder
trademark: Featured dangerous, manipulative women in his films

name: Anthony Russo
trademark: No info

name: Andrew Stanton
trademark: Uses music by Thomas Newman

name: Bob Persichetti
trademark: No info

name: Lee Unkrich
trademark: No info

name: Mel Gibson
trademark: Intense acting style

name: Sam Mendes
trademark: Music scores from Thomas Newman

name: John Lasseter
trademark: Uses music by Randy Newman

name: Gus Van Sant
trademark: Often uses shot of cloud formation (e.g. Elephant, Drugstore Cowboy, Gerry, Paranoid Park, and Psycho)

name: Richard Marquand
trademark: No info

name: Darren Aronofsky
trademark: Flawed but sympathetic leading characters

name: Michel Gondry
trademark: Surreal settings and visual effects

name: Stanley Donen
trademark: No info

name: Orson Welles
trademark: Low angles

name: Guy Ritchie
trademark: Numerous plot threads that intersect and assist in each other's payoffs

name: Brian De Palma
trademark: [Split screen] Often uses split screens (created optically or using a split diopter while shooting) to build suspense and/or convey story information. This allows the audience to choose what to look at and engages them further in the story (Phantom of the Paradise (1974), Carrie (1976), Dressed to Kill (1980), Blow Out (1981), The Bonfire of the Vanities (1990), Mission: Impossible (1996), Snake ...

name: George Roy Hill
trademark: The use of Jump cuts in action sequences

name: David Lean
trademark: Trains/locomotives playing a significant role in the film's plot (e.g., Brief Encounter (1945), The Bridge on the River Kwai (1957), Summertime (1955), Doctor Zhivago (1965), etc.).

name: Robert Mulligan
trademark: No info

name: Pete Docter
trademark: His films often feature the main character protecting a child in some way.

name: Michael Mann
trademark: Most of his movies contain a group of people using a speaker phone. The person on the other end always asks, "Who am I talking to?" and one of the others will rattle off a list of names (Heat (1995) and Manhunter (1986)).

name: Peter Farrelly
trademark: Films often contain flashback scenes that show how a character was affected by a traumatic event

name: Curtis Hanson
trademark: Characters in his films often reference or are seen watching movies from the Golden Age of cinema.

name: John McTiernan
trademark: Connecting separate shots with a camera pan

name: Terry Gilliam
trademark: Frequently casts Jonathan Pryce, Katherine Helmond, Michael Palin, John Cleese, Eric Idle, Robin Williams, Johnny Depp, Jeff Bridges, Christopher Plummer, Peter Stormare and Tom Waits.

name: Stanley Kramer
trademark: No info

name: Joseph L. Mankiewicz
trademark: No info

name: Clint Eastwood
trademark: His leading ladies are almost never played by an A-list actress

name: John Sturges
trademark: Predominantly male ensemble casts.

name: Ron Howard
trademark: Frequently uses music by James Horner and songs by Randy Newman.

name: Ernst Lubitsch
trademark: In most of his comedies, he took up serious subjects and spiced them with elegance, sophistication, cynicism and witty lines - It became known as "the Lubitsch Touch."

name: John Huston
trademark: Frequently cast Humphrey Bogart

name: Paul Thomas Anderson
trademark: His films often have family relationships as a major theme

name: Sergio Pablos
trademark: No info

name: Martin McDonagh
trademark: Often casts Zeljko Ivanek, Colin Farrell, Woody Harrelson, Abbie Cornish and Sam Rockwell

name: James McTeigue
trademark: No info

name: David Lynch
trademark: Constant references to dreams as a way of connecting the plot and twists in his  films.

name: Gavin O'Connor
trademark: Often works with Ben Affleck

name: Ethan Coen
trademark: A tense situation in a moving car. E.g. Fargo (1996), The Big Lebowski (1998), Burn After Reading (2008) and Blood Simple (1984).

name: John Carpenter
trademark: [Attribution] The words "John Carpenter's" appear before almost all of his film and TV titles (e.g., John Carpenter's Halloween (1978)).

name: Victor Fleming
trademark: No info

name: M. Night Shyamalan
trademark: Car crashes play pivotal roles in all his films: Cole reveals his gift to his mother  during a traffic jam in The Sixth Sense (1999), David "loses" his football  abilities in a car accident in Unbreakable (2000), and Graham's wife dies  in a bizarre car accident in Signs (2002).

name: Danny Boyle
trademark: His protagonists are often unsympathetic in some way

name: Peter Weir
trademark: His characters often interact with technology, especially television, in ways that harm them or surprise the viewer, e.g. the church big screen TV in The Mosquito Coast (1986); the living room TV and TV control center in The Truman Show (1998); radio playing in the barn in Witness (1985), and so on.

name: Moustapha Akkad
trademark: Is known as the grandfather of the Halloween movies

name: Elia Kazan
trademark: Frequently cast Marlon Brando and Karl Malden

name: Carol Reed
trademark: Often cast Trevor Howard

name: Jim Sheridan
trademark: Two young daughters in the family (In America, Brothers, Dream House)

name: Adam Elliot
trademark: No info

name: Joel Coen
trademark: Moving POV shots, sometimes from the perspective of moving cars

name: Lenny Abrahamson
trademark: No info

name: Michael Cimino
trademark: Characters disillusioned with the American Dream (The Deer Hunter (1978), Heaven's Gate (1980), The Sunchaser (1996)).

name: Zack Snyder
trademark: Uses wide shots and puts an emphasis on cinematography in action sequences

name: Richard Linklater
trademark: Likable easy-going lead characters

name: Wes Anderson
trademark: The titlecards are almost always in the font Futura Bold, most commonly in yellow color.

name: Denis Villeneuve
trademark: Frequently uses a song by Radiohead in his films.

name: James Mangold
trademark: Characters become unlikely couples

name: Dean DeBlois
trademark: Strong female characters

name: Michael Powell
trademark: No info

name: Lasse Hallström
trademark: No info

name: Steve McQueen
trademark: Frequently casts Michael Fassbender, utilizes Sean Bobbitt as his director of photography and Joe Walker as his editor.

name: Raoul Walsh
trademark: Although he directed in numerous "manly" genres, he is principally remembered as a master of crime dramas

name: David Yates
trademark: Use of hand-held camera

name: William Wyler
trademark: Long takes

name: Stuart Rosenberg
trademark: No info

name: George Miller
trademark: His versatility with the genres and subject matters of the films he directs

name: Tomm Moore
trademark: His film often have folklore involved.

name: Rob Reiner
trademark: Often includes references to his previous films

name: Sean Penn
trademark: Often stars in films that reflect his liberal political views

name: Giuseppe Tornatore
trademark: No info

name: Oliver Stone
trademark: Has cameos in most of his films. When he does not appear, his son Sean Stone does.

name: Terry Jones
trademark: Often played women in Monty Python, using a screechy old harridan voice.

name: F.W. Murnau
trademark: Visual storytelling without intertitles.

name: John Ford
trademark: If a doomed character plays poker, the last hand he plays before going to his death will be the "death hand" (two aces, one of them the ace of spades, and two 8s; so-called because Wild Bill Hickok held this hand when he was murdered). The hand will be shown in close-up.

name: Terry George
trademark: No info

name: Tom McCarthy
trademark: Low-key films about disparate people who become unusual surrogate families

name: Wim Wenders
trademark: Shooting on location.

name: John G. Avildsen
trademark: Underdog films complete with realistic character development and montage sequences

name: Robert Aldrich
trademark: Extreme and often selfish leading characters

name: Peter Bogdanovich
trademark: Always seen wearing a neck scarf

name: Tate Taylor
trademark: Frequently casts Octavia Spencer and Allison Janney.

name: Alan Parker
trademark: His films often have a dark, noirish look to them. They are often lit in very dark colors.

name: Garth Davis
trademark: Frequently works with Rooney Mara

name: Martin Brest
trademark: No info

name: Ron Clements
trademark: Beard

name: Lewis Milestone
trademark: No info

name: James Gunn
trademark: His spiky hair

name: Alexander Mackendrick
trademark: No info

name: Gore Verbinski
trademark: Frequently casts Johnny Depp.

name: Richard Attenborough
trademark: Frequently made films with a moral message or a liberal political perspective

name: William Friedkin
trademark: [Car Chase] His films often feature a pivotal car chase (The French Connection (1971), To Live and Die in L.A. (1985), Jade (1995)).

name: Brad Bird
trademark: Most of his films are set in the 1950s or a retro time period

name: Lars von Trier
trademark: Often casts Charlotte Gainsbourg.

name: Franklin J. Schaffner
trademark: Frequently directed films based off books.

name: Gary Trousdale
trademark: Films rarely contain opening credits

name: Robert Wise
trademark: No info

name: Harold Ramis
trademark: Deep resonant voice

name: Morten Tyldum
trademark: No info

name: Richard Kelly
trademark: Frequently casts Beth Grant, Holmes Osborne, and Lisa K. Wyatt

name: Otto Preminger
trademark: Bald, clean-shaven head

name: Mel Brooks
trademark: His main characters often stop and sarcastically direct a line to the camera/audience

name: Kevin Costner
trademark: Frequently appears in Westerns

name: Byron Howard
trademark: The protagonists are usually an optimist and their cynical friend, ending with the cynic becoming more open

name: Paul Greengrass
trademark: Stories based on real-life events.

name: Barry Levinson
trademark: Film editing by Stu Linder in the majority of his films.

name: Joss Whedon
trademark: Frequent use of nouns as adjectives, by adding the suffix "-y"

name: Charles Laughton
trademark: Powerful, penetrating shouting voice, developed during his stage-acting time

name: Robert Hamer
trademark: No info

name: Jacques Tourneur
trademark: No info

name: Mike Nichols
trademark: Often includes extremely long starting and/or ending shots taken from high in the air, for example Working Girl (1988) and Angels in America (2003).

name: Gabriele Muccino
trademark: Character named Ristuccia.

name: Edward Zwick
trademark: In terms of television, has frequently worked with Marshall Herskovitz

name: Spike Jonze
trademark: Green and blue tinged scenes lit by fluorescents

name: Norman Jewison
trademark: No info

name: Richard Brooks
trademark: No info

name: Tom Hooper
trademark: Often directs historical dramas and period pieces

name: Howard Hawks
trademark: His female characters are frequently "just one of the guys," coining the term "Hawksian Women."

name: Billy Bob Thornton
trademark: Southern American accent

name: Woody Allen
trademark: Films his dialog using long, medium-range shots instead of the typical intercut  close-ups

name: Henry Selick
trademark: [stop motion] Uses stop motion puppets or special effects in all of his films.
